job_title: Visitor Services Assistant in Montrose, Scotland
pros:
- some of the colleagues are wonderful to work with and truly make the day fly by
- working in a historic property/site is fascinating if you’re into that thing
- at my property we could spend a lot of time outside in the sunshine with the visitors while doing our job
cons:
- management above property level have no idea what a day as a VSA involves. They also like to tell you how to do your job even when it won’t work. “Change the tour like this...” “we don’t have the staff for that and it won’t work with the layout of the property” “...make it work”. 
- budgets are always ridiculous. They expect so much but don’t give you the resources to accomplish what they want.
- some of the conditions we work in aren’t great. Spending a day in a shed - I mean, “shop” - when it’s freezing isn’t fun.
- they don’t value key staff. Our chef (literal chef, not a home baker with a food hygiene certificate) made our property more popular with her menu and customer service. Management didn’t listen to her great ideas or what our visitors had to say about the cafe. So she left.
